hierarchy.file_name: Impact--Exclude unmapped/mis-mapped lifecycle records from forecasting + lifecycle analytics.docx

sections.text:
This change improves the accuracy and trustworthiness of forecasting and lifecycle analytics by ensuring we only aggregate on canonical lifecycle values. Today, when lifecycle mappings are missing or incorrect, our rollups can unintentionally fall back to raw CRM stage names, which introduces inconsistent categorization and silently contaminates key outputs.

By excluding records flagged with lifecycle mapping errors (e.g., unmapped stages or missing required fields), stage-based rollups and derived metrics—like conversion rates and slippage signals—will reflect only properly defined lifecycle progressions. This reduces metric drift caused by CRM configuration changes, one-off custom stages, or incomplete data, and makes results more comparable across teams and time periods.

The user impact is that some dashboards and forecasts may show slight shifts (often downward in volume) because previously “noisy” records were being counted in stages they shouldn’t have been. The tradeoff is intentional: we’re prioritizing correctness over completeness, and making data quality issues visible rather than masking them via fallback behavior.

To protect against regressions, we’ll add targeted tests with mixed mapped/unmapped stage inputs to confirm that unmapped/mis-mapped records are excluded and cannot skew aggregations. This also creates a stable contract for future lifecycle changes: if canonical mappings aren’t present, analytics won’t guess—ensuring predictable, explainable metrics.
